terrain.surface: Gravel roads through Peak District. Significant elevation with moorland scenery.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Regional UK event. Peak District terrain with small-medium field and significant elevation.

biased_opinion.summary: Tor Divide is a regional event in UK‚ÄîPeak District terrain with significant elevation. The moorland is scenic, but the small-medium local field, regional organization, and limited prestige keep it in Tier 4.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: A solid regional UK Peak District gravel race. Worth it for UK riders. Not worth traveling internationally for.

final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're local to UK‚Äîyes, it's solid. If you're traveling internationally‚Äîskip it.
final_verdict.alternatives: For better UK races: Lauf Gritfest.

logistics.lodging_strategy: Peak District has lodging. Book ahead.
logistics.food: Peak District has dining. Stock nutrition.
logistics.camping: camping at an event village in Bamford on Friday night** before the Saturday morning start

history.origin_story: Regional UK Peak District gravel event.

suffering_zones.label: Late Peak District
suffering_zones.desc: Final Peak District sections before finish.

non_negotiables.why: UK weather is variable with rain possible.
Peak District requires sustained mountain effort.

marketplace_variables.race_hook_detail: Regional event with Peak District terrain.

logistics.explanation: Event village camping in Bamford with Saturday morning starts delivers solid organization, plus "a train station a stone's throw from the start" makes public transport viable. Laura describes taking away "new skills" and "a renewed sense of what's possible" from the experience, but basic details like entry fees and exact start times remain unpublished.

length.explanation: Claire Frecknall's team "averaged a mere 10kmh for the first 35km" on day one, showing how the 200km Peak Gravel and 250km Divide routes demand respect. The 32-hour cutoff and figure-eight design through Edale lets riders split it into manageable overnight segments or push through as a proper single-day challenge. Similar distance to Crusher in the Tushar.

technicality.explanation: Claire Frecknall noted "sometimes, even with wide 650b rims and 2.1" tyres, I still wished I was riding an actual mountain bike" on the Dark Peak sections. VecchioJo described Jaggers Clough as "a definite loose surface dismount and trudge," while the late-race surprise descent and hike-a-bike combo proves the route has technical teeth. Similar technical demands to Gravel Worlds.

elevation.explanation: The 5500m climbing over 250km includes Jacob's Ladder steep enough that riders camp overnight rather than attempt it in darkness. Claire Frecknall's "leg-burning climbs" through beaten-up bridleways and grassy hillsides of the Dark Peak deliver proper Peak District punishment, with VecchioJo calling the Mam Nick road up Mam Tor "unnecessarily brutal." Similar elevation profile to Gravel Worlds.

climate.explanation: Historical weather data shows average highs of 57¬∞F and lows of 44¬∞F, with a 65% chance of rain on any given day, and gusts reaching 26 mph. Mid-May in the Peak District means you're gambling on British spring weather, which could be anything from snow to scorching sun within the same 32-hour window. The research doesn't reveal specific weather disasters, but this is England ‚Äì pack for rain, hope for clouds, expect wind. At least you're 'never too remote from civilisation' when the weather turns. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: Peak District elevations max around 600 meters, so altitude effects are non-existent. The route crosses gritstone edges and tors, but these are hills by mountain standards - your cardiovascular system won't notice the elevation. Lower altitude than Gravel Worlds ‚Äî no thin-air concerns.

adventure.explanation: Laura "bivvied in the wild for the first time" and "strayed off the map more than once," including "five minutes of shouting 'hello?' into a patch of dense woodland." The unsupported format through Stanage and Curbar gritstone edges, combined with wild camping options, delivers proper bikepacking adventure despite the civilized setting.

prestige.explanation: "Now in its third edition" puts this firmly in baby-event territory, with organizer Valerio Stuart positioning it as "a stepping stone to bigger adventures." Laura's reflection that "your first step doesn't have to be epic" captures the event's intentionally modest ambitions - it's a training ground, not a destination race.

race_quality.explanation: No mass start format with riders leaving "whenever they were ready" creates a relaxed atmosphere but lacks competitive structure. The 32-hour cutoff accommodates weekend warriors, while fastest finishers completed routes in 11-13 hours on full-suspension mountain bikes, showing the time gaps reflect equipment choices more than racing depth.

experience.explanation: Stanage and Curbar edges deliver Peak District grit, and the technical singletrack near the finish will separate the tourists from the riders. That late-race 20km surprise descent into a hike-a-bike shows someone knows how to design suffering. A 13-year-old and her mum camping at Jacob's Ladder still finished in 36 hours proves the route has soul. As Laura puts it: "I came away from the Tor Divide and the Tor Divide Bursary with an experience I'll carry with me for a lifetime - new skills, a renewed sense of what's possible, and an even greater curiosity for the ..."

community.explanation: Event village camping in Bamford with post-ride pizza sounds cozy, but we're talking about a field so small they won't publish participation numbers. Claire Frecknall's endorsement about 'packing comfortable walking shoes' tells you this attracts more hikers than hammers. The 'larger than usual percentage of female participants' is promising, but hard to build legends with mystery attendance.

field_depth.explanation: Fastest finishers completed routes in 11-13 hours on full-suspension bikes while others took over 30 hours, showing huge time gaps that reflect participation levels more than competitive depth. VecchioJo observed riders ranging from "complete first timers" to veterans, confirming this attracts recreational participants testing bikepacking gear. Thinner field than Ouray Gravel Grinder.

value.explanation: Laura describes connecting with "two fellow Peak Gravellers in Bakewell" for an "unexpected" wild camp and shared final miles, showing the event delivers spontaneous adventure. The inclusive atmosphere where riders are welcomed "whether zipping along for a speed demon time or taking it at a pace to savour the views" maximizes the experience regardless of ability.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs ¬£75-95. They won't publish entry fees, which usually means they're either embarrassingly cheap or embarrassingly expensive. UK location means international travel costs, and Peak District accommodation gets pricey during tourist season. The included camping softens the blow, but you're still looking at European event pricing without European event prestige. Higher total cost than Badlands.

key_takeaways: " One reviewer stated the route was "challenging in places" and warned that riders should bring "the biggest tyres you could possibly fit" on a gra
The Tor Divide is "now in its third edition" as of 2026, meaning it first ran in 2024

front_rear_split.rationale: Faster front for reduced rolling resistance on straights, grippier rear for traction on loose climbs and corners

youtube_data.search_query: Tor Divide gravel race Peak District

videos.title: Great Whyte Creations - The Tor Divide - 200km gravel bikepacking epic through the Peak District
videos.description:
A bikepacking challenge across the Peak District üö≤ 
No labels. 
No categories. 
It‚Äôs just about 
having fun riding a bike.

Pack what you need,
come out and ride, 
be it at party pace or
with a knife between your teeth. 


https://tordivide.co.uk

videos.curation_reason: Highest view count with engaging first-person bikepacking experience and good atmosphere capture.

videos.title: Bikepacking The Peak Gravel Overnighter - Tor Divide
videos.description:
Hi all,

I‚Äôve recently come back from a wet bikepacking weekend hosted by Tor Divide guys. The ride started in Manchester City Centre heading out to a campsite in the beautiful Peak District that was booked by the organisers on the Saturday night, returning on the Sunday for beer and medals. What else could you ask for on this Peak Gravel Overnighter?

Typically, the weather was not kind to us from about 10am Saturday morning - the rain started and would stay with us untill about 3am Sunday morning. Despite this, we managed to keep our spirits high and have a laugh all the same.

We were going to sit around the campfire and tell stories of past trips and enjoy the evening under the stars. This quickly changed into a session at the pub, eating and drinking until we had dried out.

Our return route took in my favourite road in the Peak (because it‚Äôs closed) - Mam Tor, a famous road that is being reclaimed by nature as her own. 

Sunshine and skids were the theme of the Sunday's return route of the Peak Gravel Overnighter; we packed up our wet (and broken) tents and cycled back via a cafe stop or two. The finish line was Balance Brewery - a company that wasn‚Äôt scared to experiment with British ingredients through modern interpretations.

All of this on just a back brake - the front just disappeared on the morning of day one. 

Big thanks to the Tor Divide guys for getting us there and back safely with a lot of good banter in between. 

It was amazing to meet so many new like-minded people and make some new friends, that‚Äôs what this is all about!

üçï If you enjoyed this film, you can show your support in pizza form by this link  https://buymeacoffee.com/allenboardman üçï 

Though I'd love it if you just tuned in from time to time ü§üüèª 

See you out there! 

-Allen

Proudly supported by Acepac Bikepacking Bags https://www.acepac.bike/en/

0:00 Start
1:00 Where am I?
2:04 so much rain 
4:02 Bus stop shelter 
5:14 Pub for tea 
6:43 Good morning!
7:36 Mam Tor
10:54 NCN back to the start.

videos.title: Tor Divide 2025 / Bikepacking in the Peak District
videos.description:
I didn‚Äôt ride the Tour Divide‚Ä¶ I rode the Tor Divide ‚Äî a cheeky 200km off-road bikepacking route through the Peak District. And honestly? It was bloody brilliant.

This was no sufferfest. Bone-dry trails, stunning views, and some of the best gravel the UK has to offer. The Tor Divide might not have bears or altitude, but it does have endless climbs and rocky descents.

I rode the whole thing in one day ‚Äî started at 8am, finished at 1:15am.

This is my take on the UK‚Äôs answer to the Tour Divide ‚Äî a ride that punches above its weight and left me smiling (and only slightly dusty).

Join this channel and watch upcoming videos before anybody else!
https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC7Sn5BSyeebQdMJtQ4jVqsw/join

If you enjoy the channel and would like to show your support you can find me on: https://buymeacoffee.com/mraudax - Thank you!

- Cycling gear -
Coros Dura Bike Computer
Tailfin Top Bag
Tailfin Aeropack + Carbon Rack
RedShift Quick Release Aero Bars
Redshift Suspension seat post and Stem
Charge Spoon (saddle)

- Bivvy / Camping gear -
Naturehike Mongar 2 Person Tent - https://amzn.to/3ColHBZ
Hunka XL Bivvy Bag - https://alpkit.com/products/hunka-xl?variant=41470529667177
UL80 Trekology Sleeping Pad - https://amzn.to/3ZGQLtT

videos.curation_reason: Comprehensive first-person single-day race recap with detailed course information and good production quality.

videos.title: Tor Divide 2025 | Peak District Gravel | Peak District Bikepacking | Giant Revolt | Gravel Bikes
videos.description:
This was such a great day!  Thanks to Valerio and the team for putting on such a well organised event.  I had planned to do this over 2 days but due to Joe dropping out to go hiking instead, it meant I was in a better position to smash the ride out in a single day and not take a fully loaded bike out on the route.

The Tor Divide is a non-competitive, self-supported bikepacking adventure that challenges riders to tackle trails, bridleways, and scenic roads on a fixed route. 

Whether you're a seasoned explorer or new to the world of bikepacking, this event offers three route options to suit your style. No prizes‚Äîjust the thrill of the ride, the freedom of the open trail, and the glory of finishing on your own terms.

Official website: https://tordivide.co.uk/

üì≤Connect with me!

Instagram https://www.instagram.com/the_yorkshire_wheeler/

YouTube https://www.youtube.com/@theyorkshirewheeler  

Make sure you change the Quality to 4k for the best viewing experience.

üëçPlease support the channel by subscribing, leaving a like and commenting.

00:00 Tor Divide start
2:43 Mam Tor Broken Road
3:23 Tor Divide
11:45 Wild Camp Bike Setup

-----------------------------------------------------
Music Credit:

videos.curation_reason: Good first-person race experience focusing on the challenging terrain and climbing aspects.

videos.title: Tor Divide 2025
videos.description: 200km ish two day Gravel Ride around the Peak District

quotes.text: 200k, 4,000 meters of climbing, which is about 12,000 ft. So, a lot of climbing, but a lot of beautiful roads, a lot of beautiful gravel trails.
I don't think we've even done a kilometer and we are straight up a big old hill. That was the first of 38 climbs, which was pretty savage - straight off the bat just up a hill.
Here is the famous broken road at Mammour. So apparently they've tried to repair it a few times and eventually just given up. You can see there the tarmac where it's just completely landslid.

key_challenges.name: Winn's Pass
key_challenges.description: Riders describe this as a very challenging climb with extreme road conditions including 10 foot drops and rocky terrain that requires walking sections.

key_challenges.name: The Broken Road
key_challenges.description: A 6.6km section that is definitely hike-a-bike terrain according to riders.

key_challenges.name: Stony Middleton climb
key_challenges.description: Described by riders as a bit unpleasant, one of the chunky hills on the route.

key_challenges.name: Lord's Seat
key_challenges.description: Often boggy section that organizers suggested skipping due to wet conditions, described as a bit of a push.

terrain_notes.text: Very rocky descents that require walking sections if you're not fully confident, with good lines visible but technically challenging.
Road conditions include extreme sections with 10 foot drops that make riders grateful for their usual roads.
Boggy conditions are common, especially after rain, making some sections more of a push than a ride.

gear_mentions.text: Gravel bike worked fine for the gravel route but rider always prefers a hardtail, stating gravel bikes aren't really for them.
Small bike frames can't fit required 1.5 liters of water on the frame, requiring a hydration pack packed with snacks.

race_day_tips.text: You have 32 hours to complete the 200k route - your choice whether to sleep or go through the night for fastest time, or ride at leisurely cafe stop pace.
Plan to stop around Bakewell for overnight if doing the leisurely two-day approach.
At 30k in, riders report having done roughly 20% of the total climbing already with nearly 900 meters completed.
Event is unsupported - as long as you don't get outside help and don't sleep at a mate's house, anything else including B&Bs is fair game.

additional_quotes.text: There's mandatory kit for the route including 1.5 liters of water, and I'm taking the absolute bare minimum to try and get back before 11:00 Saturday evening.
You'll find plenty of walkers, horse riders, motor bikers - just share the space.
Come to the pub. We've got beer. We got real food. Don't be sitting in your tent all night. Come and join us.

rider_intel.search_text: Riders describe the Peak District Tor Divide as a challenging 200k gravel route with 4,000m of climbing through 38 total climbs. Key challenging sections include Winn's Pass with extreme rocky conditions and 10-foot drops, The Broken Road requiring 6.6km of hike-a-bike terrain, and the unpleasant Stony Middleton climb. Terrain features very rocky technical descents that force walking, boggy sections especially after rain, and roads with extreme drop-offs. The unsupported format allows 32 hours to complete with options to sleep or ride through. Riders report completing 20% of climbing in first 30k. Mandatory kit includes 1.5 liters of water. Route shares space with walkers, horse riders, and motor bikers. Weather can bring consistent rain making conditions more challenging. Popular strategy includes overnight stops around Bakewell for two-day approach.

photos.alt: Cyclist pushing bike up steep cobblestone climb through green countryside with stone walls and fields - Tor Divide - Peak District, UK
Gravel cyclist in racing kit riding through rural British countryside with green fields and hedgerows - Tor Divide - Peak District, UK
Race participant in down jacket being interviewed next to Tor Divide bikepacking challenge banner at event finish - Peak District, UK
Course preview from Tor Divide race footage
